title: Current Use and Intention to Use Contraception by Empowerment
unit_of_measure: Percentage among young women age 15-29
table_data: [["", "Intention to use (among non-users)", "Current use"], ["Low Empowerment", 35.8, 4.2], ["Medium Empowerment", 45.6, 7.3], ["High Empowerment", 60.7, 18.6]]
table_text: In Nigeria, young women with high empowerment are much more likely to be currently using contraception than those with low empowerment, and among non-users, those with high empowerment are much more likely to intend to use in the future than those with low empowerment.

title: Women and men seeking treatment for STIs
unit_of_measure: Percentage
table_data: [["", "Women", "Men"], ["Clinic/hospital/private doctor/other health professional", 40, 45], ["Advice or medicine from shop/pharmacy", 22, 27], ["Advice or treatment from any other source", 11, 11], ["No advice or treatment", 27, 20]]
table_text: Figure 13.1 shows that 40 percent of women sought advice or treatment from a clinic, hospital, private doctor, or other health professional; 22 percent sought advice or medicine from a shop or pharmacy; and 27 percent sought no advice or treatment. Men were more likely than women to seek advice or treatment for STIs or STI symptoms, with 45 percent seeking advice or treatment from a health facility or health professional and 27 percent from a shop or pharmacy.

title: Maternal mortality ratios with confidence intervals for the seven years preceding the 2008 NDHS and the 2013 NDHS

table_data: [["Seven years preceding the 2008 NDHS (2001-2008)", 475, 545, 615], ["Seven years preceding the 2013 NDHS (2006-2013)", 500, 576, 652]]
table_text: Figure 14.2, the confidence interval surrounding the maternal mortality ratio of 576 deaths per 100,000 live births is 500-652, while the confidence interval for the 2008 ratio of 545 deaths per 100,000 live births is 475-615, showing that the MMR confidence intervals overlap for the 2008 and 2013 surveys.

title: Trends in current use of family planning, Egypt 1980-2014

title: Percentage of births whose mothers are amenorrheic, abstaining, or insusceptible to the risk of pregnancy
table_text: Figure 7.1 shows, the percentage of babies whose mothers are amenorrheic declines from over 95 percent in the two months immediately after a birth to 52 percent during the period two to three months after birth. By 4 to 5 months after a birth, mothers of only 36 percent of births are still amenorrheic, and by 12 to 13 months after a birth, mothers have not resumed menstruation in the case of only 16 percent of births. The median duration of postpartum amenorrhea is 3.4 months.

title: Percentage of births whose mothers are amenorrheic, abstaining, or insusceptible to the risk of pregnancy
table_text: As in other Islamic countries, many couples in Egypt observe the traditional practice of abstaining from sexual relations for a period of 40 days after a birth. Reflecting this tradition, the percentage of births for which the mother is still abstaining decreases rapidly, from 77 percent immediately (0-1 months) after a birth to 16 percent at 2 to 3 months after a birth.

title: Percentage of births whose mothers are amenorrheic, abstaining, or insusceptible to the risk of pregnancy
table_text: The combined effects of postpartum amenorrhea and postpartum abstinence are reflected in the period of postpartum insusceptibility after a birth. Overall, 60 percent of women are susceptible to the risk of pregnancy at 4-5 months after a birth, and around 75 percent are susceptible at 8 to 9 months after a birth.

title: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) with confidence intervals for the seven years preceding the KDHS
unit_of_measure: Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births
table_data: [["Seven years preceding the 2003 Kenya DHS (1996-2003)", 398, 506, 614], ["Seven years preceding the 2008-09 Kenya DHS (2002-2009)", 343, 520, 696], ["Seven years preceding the 2014 Kenya DHS (2007-2014)", 254, 362, 471]]
table_text: However, the confidence intervals surrounding the estimates around the 2008-09 (CI: 343, 696) and 2014 (CI:254, 471) estimates overlap, such that the estimate of 362 deaths per 1,000 population (2014 KDHS) is encompassed within the 2008-09 confidence interval, but the 2008-09 estimate (520 deaths per 1,000 population) is not encompassed within the 2014 confidence interval.

title: Percentage of women age 15-49 circumcised by ethnic group
unit_of_measure: Percent
table_text: The proportion of women who are circumcised varies by ethnic group (Figure 18.1), with the majority of women in the Somali (94 percent), Samburu (86 percent), Kisii (84 percent), and Maasai (78 percent) groups being circumcised. In contrast, 2 percent or less of women in the Luo, Luhya, Turkana, and Mijikenda/Swahili ethnic groups are circumcised.

title: Cost of care
unit_of_measure: Percent distribution of outpatient medical care cost
table_data: [["", "Free", "1-99 Jordanian Dinars", "100+ Jordanian Dinars"], ["Any facility", 51, 43, 6], ["Public facility", 76, 21, 3], ["Private facility", 28, 63, 9]]

title: Control over women’s earnings

title: Trends in knowledge of causes of malaria

title: Trends in household ownership of ITNs
unit_of_measure: Percentage of households owning at least one insecticide-treated net (ITN) and percentage of households with at least one net for every two persons
table_text: Household ownership of at least one ITN increased substantially from 23% in the 2004-05 TDHS to 91% in the 2011-12 THMIS, declined to 66% in the 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, and then increased to 78% in the 2017 TMIS.
linearized_input: Trends in household ownership of ITNs | Percentage of households owning at least one insecticide-treated net (ITN) and percentage of households with at least one net for every two persons | (1+ ITN, 2004-05 TDHS, 23) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2004-05 TDHS, 10) (1+ ITN, 2007-08 THMIS, 39) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2007-08 THMIS, 15) (1+ ITN, 2010 TDHS, 64) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2010 TDHS, 23) (1+ ITN, 2011-12 THMIS, 91) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2011-12 THMIS, 56) (1+ ITN, 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, 66) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, 39) (1+ ITN, 2017 TMIS, 78) (1+ ITN/2 people, 2017 TMIS, 45)
target: Household ownership of at least one ITN increased substantially from 23% in the 2004-05 TDHS to 91% in the 2011-12 THMIS, declined to 66% in the 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, and then increased to 78% in the 2017 TMIS.
blueprint: 91. How much did household ownership of an ITN add in the 2011-12 THMIS? | 66%. In the 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, what was the household ownership of at least one ITN? | 78%. How much did household ownership of at least one ITN increase to in the 2017 TMIS? |
blueprint_target: Blueprint: 91. How much did household ownership of an ITN add in the 2011-12 THMIS? | 66%. In the 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, what was the household ownership of at least one ITN? | 78%. title: Trends in ITN access and use
unit_of_measure: Percentage of the household population with access to an ITN and percentage of the population that slept under an ITN the night before the survey
table_text: The percentage of the household population with access to an ITN increased from 16% in the 2004-05 TDHS to 75% in the 2011-12 THMIS, dropped to 56% in the 2015-16 TDHS-MIS, and then rose to 63% in the 2017 TMIS.

title: Trends in IPTp use by pregnant women
unit_of_measure: Percentage of women with a live birth in the 2 years before the survey who received at least 1, 2, or 3 doses of SP/Fansidar
table_text: The percentage of women receiving IPTp1+ increased from 53% in the 2004-05 TDHS to 83% in the 2017 TMIS, the percentage receiving IPTp2+ increased from 22% to 56% between these surveys, and the percentage receiving IPTp3+ increased from 3% to 26% between the 2 surveys.

title: Trends in care seeking for children with fever by source of care

title: Trends in artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) use by children under age 5
unit_of_measure: Among children under 5 with recent fever who took an antimalarial, percentage who received ACT
table_text: Use of ACT among children under age 5 who took an antimalarial increased by 53 percentage points between the 2004-05 TDHS (8%) and the 2011-12 THMIS (61%), and there was a 28 percentage point increase between the 2011-12 THMIS and the 2017 TMIS (from 61% to 89%).

title: Attitude towards malaria and malaria treatment
unit_of_measure: Percentage of women age 15-49 who strongly agree with the following statements about malaria
table_data: [["I can easily get treatment if my child gets malaria", 72], ["My family rarely gets malaria", 73], ["It is important to take the entire course of malaria medicine to make sure the disease will be fully cured", 94], ["ACTs can be obtained at nearest health facility or duka la dawa muhimu", 88], ["The only way to be sure someone has malaria is to test their blood", 92]]
table_text: The percentages of women who strongly agree with the statements were as follows: I can easily get treatment if my child gets malaria (72%), My family rarely gets malaria (73%), It is important to take the entire course of malaria medicine to make sure the disease will be fully cured (94%), ACTs can be obtained at the nearest health facility or duka la dawa muhimu (88%), and The only way to be sure someone has malaria is to test their blood (92%).

title: Trends in ITN ownership

title: Opinions and beliefs about malaria
unit_of_measure: Percentage of women age 15-49 who agree with specific statements about malaria
table_data: [["", "Among women age 15-49 who state there are ways to avoid getting malaria, percentage who report that SP/Fansidar can be given to a pregnant woman to help her avoid getting malaria"], ["I sleep under a bednet every night because it is the best way to avoid getting malaria", 94], ["I can easily hang a mosquito net", 95], ["Pregnant women should still take the medicine that is meant to keep them from getting malaria even if they sleep\u2026", 91], ["I take the entire course of malaria medicine to make sure the disease will be fully cured", 96], ["It is important to take a child to a health provider the same or next day after the child gets a fever", 97], ["My community is able to come together to take action to prevent malaria among its members", 74]]
table_text: Overall, 94% of women agree that they sleep under a bed net every night because it is the best way to avoid getting malaria; 95% agree they can easily hang a net; 91% agree that pregnant women should still take the medicine meant to keep them from getting malaria even if they sleep under nets every night; 97% agree that it is important to take a child to a health provider the same or next day after the child gets a fever; and 96% agree that they should take the entire course of malaria medicine to make sure the disease will be fully cured.

title: Total Fertility Rates by Selected Background Characteristics
unit_of_measure: Number of Children

title: Male Circumcision by Region
unit_of_measure: Percent of men age 15-49 who are circumcised
table_text: The prevalence of male circumcision is lowest in Rukwa (28%), Simiyu (30%), and Shinyanga (32%). In contrast, male circumcision in Zanzibar, Dar es Salaam, Mtwara, Tanga, Lindi, and Pwani regions is almost universal.

title: Infant and Child Mortality Rates for the Ten-year Period Preceding the Survey
unit_of_measure: Deaths per thousand
table_text: The highest infant mortality is found in Nampula (216 per thousand) and the lowest in Maputo City (49 per thousand), eg., the probability of dying during the first year of life is 4.4 times higher for a child born in Nampula than for a child born in Maputo city.

title: Contraceptive prevalence rate by method type, Nigeria 2013 DHS
unit_of_measure: Percentage
table_text: Overall, 26% of the women were using any method of contraception, with 17% using a modern method and 9% using traditional means (Figure 3).
